abstract.para: My Expenses is an app for tracking expenses and incomes with Android, designed for compatibility with desktop finance tools.
We explain here the new feature introduced in 1.5.0: Payment methods

sect1.title: New in 1.5.0.: Payment methods
sect1.para: Through this new channel, I will publish regularly explanations and discussions of My Expenses's functionality. In contrast to the tutorial, which I try to keep consistent with the current release, and which is translated to all supported languages, these articles are meant to document new features, as they arise, to generate comments from users and hence to contribute to the app's continuos improvement.

In answer to requests voiced already by its first users, version 1.5.0. of My Expenses introduced payment methods. The functionality is equivalent to how payment methods work in Grisbi: Payment methods are linked to accounts through account types. When you create an account, you define its type as one of CASH, BANK, ASSET or LIABILITY. When you create transactions in a given account, you can then make use of the payment methods that are linked to its account type.
Through the "Manage payment methods" activity from the preferences screen, you can change, add and delete methods.

My Expenses has four predefined payment methods, all of them by default linked only to bank accounts: CHEQUE, CREDITCARD, DEPOSIT, DIRECTDEBIT. Those cannot be deleted, or renamed, but you can alter their association with account types. Clicking on a method or activating the New button brings you to the following screen:

Here you decide if the method should only be used for expenses (credit), incomes (debit), or both (neutral). And you check the account types where you want to make use of it. Now in the edit screen for transactions you will see a line labeled Method, with a button opening the dialog where you select one of the applicable methods for the transaction.

Unfortunately, payment methods are not yet expressed in the QIF export, because the standard does not provide a field for this information. If you have an idea on how to export transactions in a more expressive format, let me know.

abstract.para: We explain here a feature introduced in 1.6.0: templates.

sect1.title: New feature in upcoming 1.6.0 release: Templates
sect1.para: My Expenses now tries to help you enter recurrent transactions: say you often eat a fixed-priced meal in your favourite restaurant, or transfer the same amount of money from one account to the other, or buy the weekly magazine at your newsstand, you name it. After you have entered the transaction once, you call the Create template command from its context menu:
Enter a title for the template:
Templates are available through the New button's popup window.

Clicking on a template's title results in the instantiation of a new transaction with all information (amount, category, comment, payee, payment method) from the template. Only time and date reflect the current moment.
In the same way you can define templates for transfers. Templates are linked to accounts, so you only see templates defined for the current account in the popup menu.
Inspecting the list of templates and deleting the ones you no longer need, is available from the preferences.
Beta 1 of 1.6.0 is available from Github's Downloads and shortly through F-Droid.
